titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the John Stremlau Papers FA039

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-07-01 00:16:53 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged in five series:
Series 3 - Rockefeller Foundation - Soviet Studies Competition
The original order and file titles have been maintained wherever possible.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted are noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Rockefeller Archive Center has title, copyright, and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them, and has authority to grant permission to cite and publish archival material from the collection.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: John Stremlau (b. 1944) graduated from Wesleyan University (B.A. 1966) and the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy (M.A. 1967, M.A.L.D. 1968, Ph.D. 1974).

He joined the Rockefeller Foundation in 1974 to help establish the Conflict in International Relations Program, in which he continued to be active until its termination in 1987. Dr. Stremlau was a Program Associate (1974-1975) and Assistant Director (1976-1976) of the Social Science Program, and Assistant Director (1976-1979), Associate Director (1979-1983), and Acting Director (1984-1987) of the International Relations Program of the Rockefeller Foundation.

The program supported relevant research and training on an international scale in the areas of international security and economic relations. Activities included aid in the development of new international relations research and training institutions in China, Southeast Asia, the Middle East, Latin America, and Africa.

Dr. Stremlau left the Rockefeller Foundation in 1987 to work with the Rockefeller Family and Associates, in cooperation with Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government, as the Director of the Pocantico Project, intended to create an institute for science and technology in international affairs. Action on the project was deferred in 1988, and Dr. Stremlau then worked with the World Bank, the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation, the Pew Charitable Trusts, the Kettering Foundation, and Rhodes University. In 1989, Dr. Stremlau became a Deputy Director of Policy Planning with the U. S. State Department, serving until 1994, when he became a senior advisor to the Carnegie Commission on Preventing Deady Conflict. From 1998 to 2006 he taught international relations at the University of Witwatersrand, Johannesburg. He became vice president for peace programs at the Carter Center in 2006.
He is the author of "International Politics of the Nigerian Civil War" (Princeton, 1977), and the editor of "The Foreign Policy Priorities of Third World States" (Westview Press, 1982).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of personal and office correspondence, clippings, conference information and proceedings, memoranda, and reports.

Documented in this collection are Stremlau's activities as RF Program Officer. It includes peer reviews and evaluations of grants proposed by other Foundation divisions. Stremlau was also a member of the staff committee (1976-1986) overseeing the RF's international conference center in Bellagio, Italy, and these activities are documented in the files.
The collection's strengths are in the documentation of the communication and cooperation between philanthropies, and an individual foundation officer's interaction with the world of his program area.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Emily J. Oakhill completed processing of this collection on July 26, 1989. Processing Level 3: Standard Processing. All material is available in acid free manuscript boxes and folders.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: John Stremlau gave his papers to the Rockefeller University in 1989.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series is composed of subject files kept by Stremlau during his time at the Rockefeller Foundation. They do not directly concern the RF or its programs, but consist of personal non-RF related matters, unsolicited correspondence and publications, and persons and organizations parallel to RF interests. The files deal with many aspects of American foreign policy during the period.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is arranged in alphabetical order by organization , title, or personal name.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes reports from various Rockefeller Foundation programs, analysis of programs and budgets.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These records document the process by which $2,000,000 was granted to institutions involved with research, training and education in the field of Soviet/U. S. international relations. The records trace the program from the first suggestion in 1981; documentation of previous, current and future interests in the area; the announcement which called for proposals from institutions; the selection committee; the proposals; the evaluations; and the awards. The Rand-UCLA Center for the Study of Soviet International Behavior and the Averell Harriman Institute of Advanced Study of the Soviet Union each received $1,000,000 grants. Both applications are included in the files, with lists of others who applied.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: This material was retained when the remainder of the Pocantico Institute records were offered to Harvard University.

appraisal.head: Appraisal
appraisal.p: This material was kept because it related to the Rockefeller Foundation, yet is not within the same time-frame as the Rockefeller Foundation series.
